This comment is not about the content of the video as a whole - slavery, the civil war, and the general treatment of the black community historically is really awful.
But, I have to say:
As a mom, I am a little uncomfortable subjecting my son to your videos. There is a lot of sub-text and innuendo in your videos - to the point it is fairly obvious (to me) what some of your political beliefs may be. I don't think it's fair and makes me profoundly sad. Unfortunately, you are part of my son's curriculum. I have to spend days transcribing your videos, taking out all of the opinions to just get to the facts that I know will be on his quizzes. Why are teachers doing this? Teach all sides, good, bad and the ugly without personal reflections. If you feel the need to personally reflect on something that is important to you, do it - but make sure you also present any opposing views. Obviously, this is only for political opinions - we all agree slavery is a very bad institution.
What got my attention? You said three things that were bias and influencing the subconscious of students to your personal views:
1)You mentioned Republicans at the time of Grant's election said, "Man, we would sure win more elections if black people could vote" - then followed up with the comment - "which is something you hear Republicans say all the time these days." - what did you mean by this? To me, knowing what I know about the mainstream belief about modern Republicans, I interpret this as sarcastic - because the mainstream belief is that Republicans want to disenfranchise the black vote. If this is your meaning, shame on you. It is not the truth - it's a lie. Personally, my family and I have sacrificed to protect the ideas of a government by the people, for the people - a family lineage of total commitment to this philosophy. Why would we want to keep anyone from their right to vote? It's absurd. In the military, soldiers are taught, day one, that everyone bleeds red. Sure, you will find pockets of racism and people who want to suppress votes - but it is not a collective mindset of the modern and historical Republican Party - quite the opposite. Nothing would please me more to see a tremendous amount of healing for the black community which seems to be in so much pain. It all breaks my heart. I intend to be a part of the solution - your videos, at times are divisive. They do not paint a full picture of the political climate of America and are therefore not part of the solution. Your bias is showing - please stop.
2) "That is why Republicans dominated the south" (because Republicans were part of the process of liberation) "just like today - except totally different" - what is wrong with you? seriously - this is BS - you are infecting the minds of our youth.
3) "Sadly we have an electoral college in the US" ... some of us think it's a great thing - look at the colors of the districts after an election - for any student that made it this far - look at the US map colors of the districts of the voting map - and ask yourself - is it really fair to have a major part of the country not represented fairly? population alone would mean the urban highly populated areas would rule the country where the rural areas that by their nature of farming - needs more area - less densely populated - would not have an equal footing on a national level. This was done by design and is an absolutely brilliant system.

One comment about land reform: the original name of the Freedman's Bureau was the Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands (or something very close to that). I think that the plan to re-distribute plantation land to freedmen might have worked if the Radicals had adopted a broad conception of "abandoned" lands. For instance, if they had said that, in declaring themselves a separate entity from the United States, former Confederate planters had basically forfeited any claim they had to property rights granted by the US government. So once their land had officially been re-incorporated into the US, it could have been considered "abandoned," and eligible for re-distribution among the former slaves.

My ancestors from Bohemia were non-slave holding farmers in the Texas hill country when the war broke out.  Like Sam Houston, they did not agree with the war.  They risked their lives to avoid fighting for a cause they did not believe in, and I am proud of them for doing so.  They were not cowards, and their descendents went on to fight in both world wars in the ensuing century.  One of them, part of Patton's army during the Sicily campaign, was bayoneted in the stomach in hand-to-hand fighting in a fox hole and left for dead.  He survived for 25 years after the war's end.

I am proud of my family's heritage of not fighting for the Confederacy, and I am proud that my grandmother and her sisters stood up for a group of young African American children walking to their separate and unequal school during the 1910s when they were being harassed by a group of older white boys.  They reported what happened to their parents, and their parents talked to the other parents.  Very quickly, they put a stop to that racist behavior.

Lincoln's position was also that the South never had the right to secede. That position was universal on the Union side; the war would not have been fought were it otherwise. Johnson's positions on Reconstruction were extremely close to Lincoln's. Where he differed from Lincoln was in charisma; he had none. He had to try to push through a hostile Congress what Lincoln would likely have been able to sweet-talk them into.

Otherwise, Johnson's provisional governors, like William Sharkey of Mississippi and Jerome Johnson (no relation) of Georgia, really were pretty decent for the most part. I'd rather have lived under one of them than someone like William Brownlow of Tennessee.

And while it's true Johnson did not win the 1868 election, putting it that way is pretty misleading. He didn't lose either; he sat it out. He would have lost had he run, true, and possibly he chose not to run to avoid that, but it's still an important distinction.
Johnson actually supported Lincoln's plans, but he wasn't a strong enough president (or well-liked enough) to get Congress to do what he wanted them to.

Essentially it all boils down to trust. The original 13 states distrusted central authority (and each other). Many believed that decisions were best made locally. In other words, let the national government handle the big issues (war, treaties, interstate laws, money) and let the states have their own jurisdiction on smaller, more everyday matters (marriage, education, intrastate commerce). This is the basic concept of federalism.

The US Federal Government is one of limited, enumerated powers, and can do only what the the Constitution permits. States (though also limited through their own constitutions) have much broader powers, encompassing the general Police Power. The police power is the power to legislate and regulate for the safety, security, morality and general welfare of citizens. The federal government does accomplishes these goals but must do so through enumerated powers, such as the interstate commerce clause.
